that.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: used to refer to a person, thing, idea etc that has already been mentioned or is already known about
that.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: ‘You never cared about me.’ ‘That’s not true.’
I wish you wouldn’t say things like that.
What did you do with those sandwiches?
Victoria Street? That’s where my sister lives.
Do you remember that nice Mr Hoskins who came to dinner?
I’ve got that pain in my back again.
He killed a man once and that’s why he had to leave Ireland.
‘We’ve been cheated, ’ she said. Those were her exact words.
‘I have to go, ’ she said, and with that (=after saying that) she hung up the phone.
that.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: /ðət/ used after a noun as a relative pronoun like ‘who’, ‘whom’, or ‘which’ to introduce a clause
that.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: There are lots of things that I need to buy before the trip.
the people that live next door
They’ve got a machine that prints names on badges.
the greatest boxer that ever lived
Who was it that said ‘The Law’s an Ass’?
The day that my father died, I was on holiday in Greece.
that.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: In everyday English, that is often omitted when it is the object of the relative clause
I like the clothes that she wears
I like the clothes she wears
You do not omit that when it is the subject of the clause
The family that lives downstairs is Polish
The family lives downstairs is Polish
that.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to refer to a particular person or thing of the general type that has just been mentioned
that.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: In my opinion, the finest wines are those from France.
His own experience was different from that of his friends.
that.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to refer to a person or thing that is not near you
that.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Is that my pen you’ve got there?
That’s Eileen’s house across the road.
Look at those men in that car. What on earth are they doing?
Our tomatoes never get as big as that.
that.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used when you are not sure who is answering the telephone
that.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: USAGE: That, who, which
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You use that as a relative pronoun when saying which person or thing you are talking about
This is the friend that I told you about
They didn't have the book that I wanted
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: This is the friend I told you about
They didn't have the book I wanted
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You use who or which when adding extra information about the person or thing
She looked after her husband, who was ill
I did it myself, which was difficult
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: In clauses like this, who or which can not be omitted
She looked after her husband, that was ill
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: You use who when talking about a person  Don't use which about people
There's the man who I saw yesterday
She looked after her husband, which was ill
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[5]: You can also use that when talking about a person That is used about both people and things
There's the man that I saw yesterday
that.translation[0].note_box[0].items[6]: In clauses like this, both that and who can be omitted
There's the man I saw yesterday
that.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used after verbs, nouns, and adjectives to introduce a clause which shows what someone says or thinks, or states a fact or reason
that.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: If she said that she’d come, she’ll come.
I can’t believe that he’s only 17.
Are you sure that they live in Park Lane?
allegations that he is guilty of war crimes
The fact that he is your brother-in-law should not affect your decision.
He might have left the money for the simple reason that he didn’t know it was there.
that.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, that is often omitted Instead of saying , you say
I’m not surprised that you were upset
I’m not surprised you were upset
In formal English, that is used more often in this situation
that.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used after a phrase with ‘so’ or ‘such’ to introduce a clause that shows the result of something
that.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I was so tired that I fell asleep.
The school was so badly damaged that it had to be pulled down.
We had been away for such a long time that I had forgotten her name.
that.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: used to introduce a clause that refers to a fact, when describing it
that.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: It’s odd that I haven’t heard of you.
That anyone should want to kill her was unthinkable.
The problem is that no-one knows what will happen.
that.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: in order that something may happen or someone may do something
that.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Give us strength that we may stand against them.
that.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: used to express a wish for something to happen or be true, especially when this is not possible
that.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Oh, that she were alive to see this!
that.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: used to say how big, how much etc, especially when you are showing the size, amount etc with your hands
that.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: It was quite a large fish – about that long.
He missed hitting the car in front by that much.
that.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: as much as in the present situation or as much as has been stated
that.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: I’m sorry, I hadn’t realized the situation was that bad.
No one expected it to cost that much.
The advanced exam is more difficult, but not many students progress that far.
that.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: used to emphasize how big, bad, much etc something is
that.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: I was that embarrassed I didn’t know what to say.
